text: Pi is a list of all policies.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's always a vector and it always sums up to one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And that's really the critical move that allows us to talk about the likelihood of a policy.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That's why habit is the prior on policy and then expected free energy updates are prior on policy into a posterior because the shape of that variable is a list that sums to one.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it's a probability distribution.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So affordances are the actions that can be taken in a moment.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we're like in a grid world, the affordances will be like up, down, left, right, stay.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So it'll be like five.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Then if we're only a single time step agents, affordances are the same as policy space because we're only selecting the next action.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So let's say we have five options.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If we had an even prior across those five, it'd be like 0.2, 0.2, 0.2, 0.2.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then that could be sampled from or updated into a policy posterior action.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If we're talking about an agent that does planning, then the shape of pie is affordances raised to the power of the time steps.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So if we have five affordances and then we're doing two time steps, then pie is 25 long.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It's up, up, up, down, upright.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so it's all of the two way combinations.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the kind of exponential explosion with policy planning, which we can come back to.
